content.description:
One long pitch that climbs bottom to top along the left edge of the face.  Fun movement over slabs, roofs, and edges up to the obvious tombstone feature at the top. This lead will use all of a 60 meter rope. Back clean the first draw to reduce rope drag.

3 bolt anchor is a ways back from the summit block in solid rock.  Extending the belay with slings or the rope  will give the best view of the second. Top roping from the ground is not really an option.

FYI: the route you see at the bottom of the rappel is an unfinished project as of 9/2015.  Only the first pitch is in. 5.6 bolts and pro.
content.protection: a dozen and a half draws and slings should do.
content.location:
START: climb up boulder that chokes gulley left of "hot patootie" and "pantalones". "Moss lords of the Wasatch" is the first route in the gulley. SUPER.8  is the next route up the gulley.  Look for the blue bolts.

DESCENT: Single rope rap off the backside then walk down to base.

content.description:
Two pitches of very moderate bolted climbing ends on a ledge with very large views.

PITCH ONE

5.6:  Climb up and right through very clean and featured rock to a two bolt anchor.

PITCH TWO

5.7: Climb up past many bolts up a clean face, through a band of healthy and robust Wasatch moss to a ledge with an anchor.   The climbing is very well protected.
content.location: This route is two pitches of bolted climbing behind and to the left (south) of the small slab buttress that Hot Patootie and Los Pantalones De Alex are on. When looking directly at the slab, scramble up and left in the gulley to the south.  About 60 feet up the gulley you will find an opening in the bushes and see the white painted bolts.  To descent, rap with one 60 meter rope to the chain anchor on top of Hot Patootie.  One more short rap will get you to the base of Hot Patootie.  A second option for the second rap is to rap down the very bushy scrub oak, remove skin, and end up at the start of the route.

content.description: A very clean bolted slab up the right side of Alex Wall.  Follow bomber bolts (6 or 7) to a bolted sport anchor.  As with the rest of the wall, the route gets harder as the slab get steeper.  After climbing over a small roof, very thin moves takes you past another bolt, then to the anchor.  At the crux, you can climb left of the bolts and diagonal right to the anchor, or you can climb directly up the line of bolts and enjoy the thin goodness.  Fun slab.
content.location: The right (north) end of Alex Wall.  This is the slab that faces east and faces directly towards The Journey Home.  It is easily identified as the cleanest slab in the gulley of the Back of Beyond.

content.description:
A short climb that arches left up the slab.  The start is marked by a fixed piton that shouldn't be trusted. The first bolt being about 20 feet up.  It gets more difficult as the angle increases.

PITCH ONE

: Follow the line of bolts arching left to a ledge with a chain anchor. There is some gear placements between bolts.

SECOND PITCH:

Climb the easy and semi-loose arÃªte/ridge above the chain belay.  There are a few bolts and natural gear placements.  To descend, locate two gold chains on the back side and slightly south of the top of the formation.  Rap down the gulley to the south, back to the chain anchor of pitch one.  From here, one rap there is one more single rope rap to the ground.
content.protection: Quickdraws.  A few small to medium pieces to suppliment the spaced bolts if runouts over easy ground scare you.
content.location: The furthest left route on Alex Wall.  This is the clean slab on the west side of the Back Of Beyond.  Facing directly east, it gets sun till around 2:00.  It is easily identified while climbing The Journey Home.
